content.title: L'Hédoniste, the values of sharing and gastronomic pleasures

introduction.small: Near the Orangerie in Strasbourg, L'Hédoniste is more than a bistro: a restaurant that highlights the epicurean qualities of food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Hédoniste, the values of sharing and gastronomic pleasures

paragraphs.text:
Behind the raw and ancient look of the decoration, L'Hédoniste makes way for modernity and creativity. Amid the open kitchen, Benjamin and Julien, nicknamed Ben and Jul, are two friends who learnt their craft with the greatest in their field (luxury hotels and starred restaurants pinned to their resumes). They partnered to re-focus on the art of eating well. In time for afterwork, locals gather at the bistro and clink their glasses (from the impressive wine menu) and most especially taste the bresaola-like dried beef, the venison pate and the wild boar ham, for all cold cuts here are homemade! The highlight remains the menu itself, a bistronomic show of local flavours. According to the season, you can order an eggplant caviar with Greek-style girolle mushrooms, figs, feta cheese and pecan nuts, before diving into the copious lamb rumsteak served with butternut, sweet potatoes and marrow. Finally, indulge in the exotic fruits iced parfait in basil and coconut cream. It will take you for a journey under the tropics and back.

L'Hédoniste
1 rue Schimper
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 61 14 57

https://www.lhedoniste-restaurant.fr/

Menu: around 38.50 EUR

content.title: Aedaen Place, a hybrid experience

introduction.small: Hidden bar, art gallery, literary café… In Strasbourg, Aedaen Place chose not to choose and piles up various atmospheres inside.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aedaen Place, a hybrid experience

paragraphs.text:
First set up as an online art dealer (Aedaen standing for Art Every Day And Every Night), this Strasbourg establishment is above all a meeting spot for artists and curious enthusiasts. At once art gallery, coffee shop, bar, brasserie and even bookshop, Aedaen Place stands out with this hybrid mix, bringing a multiplicity of atmospheres to your experience. Each room reveals a particular setting, like the purple and felt boudoir, hidden behind a back door, where you can enjoy a drink inconspicuously. In this speakeasy-like bar, seeing without being seen is an art form when you stand behind the one-way mirror facing the literary café. In the latter, you will be dazzled by the book decoration, piling up against the wall and ceiling. It is a hangout for book lovers, comfortably settled in cushioned chairs, whether at breakfast, or on the terrace for tea time under the afternoon sun.

Aedaen Place
4-6 rue des Aveugles
67000 Strasbourg

Tel : +33 (0)3 90 00 90 01

https://www.aedaen-place.com/

Menu: drinks from 2 EUR

content.title: Stay at Anne's in a typical Alsatian house

introduction.small: In Strasbourg's Robertsau market gardening neighbourhood, the hotel's welcoming guestrooms will plunge you in the best Alsatian traditions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stay at Anne's in a typical Alsatian house

paragraphs.text:
Du côté de chez Anne ("Anne's way") has a mascot: Max is a friendly parrot that welcomes you at the entrance of this family house, typical of the region. Only a stone's throw from Strasbourg's historic centre, this old Alsatian three-floor building was totally renovated by the owner. It now offers five stylish rooms with flowery names ("Poppy", "Buttercup", "Cornflower" etc…), each providing a different atmosphere, but all just as cosy.
Put on the comfortable complimentary slippers and you will feel right at home. Next to the bed, each nightstand holds a book, a token of Anne's care for literature and an effort to share her favourites. Between a good novel and a soft bed, it will be tough to get out of the room for breakfast. However, full brunch being served and pastries aplenty will surely lull you in. Which is one of the many insights into the famous and enduring Alsatian sense of hospitality.

Du côté de chez Anne
4 rue de la Carpe-Haute
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 41 80 77

https://www.du-cote-de-chez-anne.com/

Rooms: from 155 EUR

content.title: Pfifferbriader, the charming winstub of Strasbourg

introduction.small: From its name alone, Pfifferbriader – “flute players” in Alsatian – traces the history of storytellers and jugglers who entertained nobles during seigniorial meals in the Middle Ages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pfifferbriader, the charming winstub of Strasbourg

paragraphs.text:
In Alsace, winemakers were accustomed to selling their production in winstubs, traditional wine bars that served a few simple dishes. Since then, the name designates a charmingly rustic restaurant, typical of the region. At the foot of Strasbourg Cathedral, Marché-aux-Cochons-de-Lait (meaning "suckling pig market") Square is full of such establishments that are elegantly lost among the half-timbered houses. Among them, Pfifferbriader welcomes traditional food lovers in a discreet and warm atmosphere. Have a seat in the light of the winemakers whose life is displayed on colourful stained-glass windows. Start by tasting a Kartoffelpuffer, a potato pancake stuffed with Munster cheese and fried onions or with lardons and baked Emmental cheese for instance, followed by stir-fried pike-perch served in Riesling sauce and spaetzle (typical regional noodles) or a sauerkraut with cold cuts, the famous emblem of Alsatian gastronomy. Finish the meal with an apple streusel with cinnamon and vanilla ice cream. A Güeter! ("enjoy your meal" in Alsatian).

Pfifferbriader
14 place du Marché-aux-Cochons-de-Lait
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 24 46 56

https://en.winstublepfiff.com/

Menu: from 24.50 EUR

content.title: Notre-Dame de Strasbourg Cathedral, the city's emblem

introduction.small: An absolute masterpiece of Gothic architecture, Strasbourg's Notre-Dame Cathedral celebrated its first millennium in September 2015.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Notre-Dame de Strasbourg Cathedral, the city's emblem

paragraphs.text:
Nearly three centuries in the building (and consecrated in 1365), this monumental pink Vosges sandstone edifice's foundations rest on the ruins of a Roman temple. Insolently defiant of the laws of verticality, its stone spire rises to 142 metres, which made it, until 1847, the highest tower in the Christian world.

After Notre-Dame de Paris, this Strasbourg gem is the second most visited monument in France, with nearly four million visitors each year. The lace stone facade, chiselled as though suspended in space, is a remarkable work of richly ornate goldsmithing.

It depicts biblical parables about the fundamentals of religious art, whose symbols are fun to try to decipher. Make sure you are at the southern gate to attend, punctually every day at 12:30 p.m., the performance of the astronomical clock, whose movements and figurines are a fascinating delight.

Cathédrale Notre Dame de Strasbourg
Place de la Cathédrale
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 21 43 34

https://www.visitstrasbourg.fr/en/discover/must-see-attractions/the-cathedral/

content.title: Roppenheim Outlets, an immense shopping centre 30 minutes from Strasbourg

introduction.small: Modern and attractive, this temple dedicated to consumption and enjoyment is one of the favourite destinations of Alsatians, tourists, and visitors from across the border.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Roppenheim Outlets, an immense shopping centre 30 minutes from Strasbourg

paragraphs.text:
If you are also in Alsace to shop, you will fall in love with this place, whose 'small village' approach immediately plunges you into a soothing and friendly atmosphere.

The profusion of shop signs, fountains, and treed areas will make this shopping destination a moment of celebration to share with family or friends. The major brands present offer their collections from previous seasons with a minimum discount of 30%. The choice is almost infinite, for all styles and budgets.

Close to a hundred shops offer the best of ready-to-wear, watches, jewellery, and home accessories, not to mention the bars and restaurants that allow you to satisfy your hunger between purchases. To get there, the easiest way is to take the free shuttle leaving from Strasbourg station.

Roppenheim The Style Outlets
1 route de l'Europe
67480 Roppenheim

+33 (0)3 88 72 77 17

https://roppenheim.thestyleoutlets.fr/en

content.title: Les Haras: a symbol of French luxury

introduction.small: Listed as a heritage site since 1922 and bordering the old-world charm of neighbouring La Petite France, this very comfortable hotel offers an astute mix of old and new.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Haras: a symbol of French luxury

paragraphs.text:
Built in the mid-18th century and butting up against the medieval walls, this remarkable complex housed the former National Stud Farm before sinking into a long sleep. Behind its brilliant renaissance are Patrick Jouin and Sanjit Manku, an ambitious architectural tandem who are masters of conceptual staging.

A clever compromise with the splendours of its rich past, this jewel of Alsatian hospitality reorganised its space to offer 55 rooms with refined elegance. A major symphony in white, punctuated with leather and blond wood, is played with talent. The sumptuous courtyard paved with Rhine pebbles leading to the lounge bar deserves special attention.

For the pinnacle of your stay, the hotel restaurant has entrusted the development of its menu to Marc Haeberlin, three-star chef of the Auberge de l'Ill in Illhaeusern; like that storied restaurant, lunch and dinner at Les Haras feature some of the great classics of French gastronomy.

Les Haras
23 rue des Glacières
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 90 20 50 00

www.les-haras-hotel.com/?lng=en

Rooms: from 135 EUR

content.title: La Petite France: a charming neighbourhood right on the water

introduction.small: South of the ‘Grand Ile' is the most picturesque district of the old city, which was largely destroyed during the Second World War.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Petite France: a charming neighbourhood right on the water

paragraphs.text:
It took a great deal of restoration work to identically restore the area to its original character. Formerly, on this popular spot, which was alive at every moment of the day, the River Ill delta encouraged the building of mills and a maze of canals. Fishermen, millers, and tanners naturally chose to settle here.

To follow their history, venture out early some bright morning and take the narrow, cobbled streets that bear witness to their medieval origins: rue du Bain-aux-Plantes (plant-washing street), rue du Fosse des Tanneurs (tanners ditch street), rue des Moulins (mill street)…

Inherited from the past, this historic walk couldn't be more charming or picturesque, as you pass a number of winstubs (typical taverns) where wine flows freely antique dealers and galleries, small shops of artisans, heirs of an ancestral knowledge, and especially the remarkable half-timbered houses, vestiges of the 16th and 17th centuries, whose silhouettes are gracefully reflected in the water.

La Petite France
67000 Strasbourg

https://www.visitstrasbourg.fr/en/discover/must-see-attractions/the-petite-france/

content.title: Les Aviateurs: an American bar for seeing and being seen

introduction.small: An absolute reference point, this is the favourite stopover for visiting celebrities, chic yuppies, and gilded youth.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Aviateurs: an American bar for seeing and being seen

paragraphs.text:
For more than 20 years, this absolute must have been the leader of the Alsatian night scene. A chic and cosy club spirit reigns here. The tone is set with a profusion of dark wood and collections of antique frames on the theme of pre-war cinema idols and aviation propellers.

Conducive to dancing and confidential trysts, the bar's 1950s neon stands out as the strategic axis, as it takes up most of the room, which immediately positions you in the heart of the party. For a pleasant evening with friends, go for the comfortable red leather upholstered sofas, or even better, the VIP lounge space.

Late at night, a DJ gives pride to the standards of the 1980s and 1990s, a sound backbone for all generations. Exhibitions and jazz evenings are the little extras that make all the difference. The capper? The service is great.

Les Aviateurs
12 rue des Sœurs
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 36 52 69

https://www.facebook.com/aviateurs/

Glass of wine: around 4.50 EUR

content.title: The ‘bateau-mouche' (riverboat): little prince of the river cruise

introduction.small: With 400 km of waterways, Alsace is the ideal playground for river tourism another approach to enjoying the charms of the region while reviving a certain idea of ​​carpe diem.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The ‘bateau-mouche' (riverboat): little prince of the river cruise

paragraphs.text:
Living on the water and also being outdoors, you can share the daily life of mariners for short outings or multi-day theme cruises. With over 800,000 annual passengers, Strasbourg Fluvial is undoubtedly one of the premiere regional tourist attractions.

In any season, from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., the imposing Batorama with its panoramic glass roof offers a comprehensive overview of the architectural and historical diversity of the city. The route is enjoyable, especially under clear skies. A string of small romantic bridges allows you to admire the old centre and its charming timbered facades, the Palais Rohan, and, of course, the cathedral. Over 70 minutes, embrace the diversity of this 'Latin Sentry at the gates of Germany' with a living slideshow that includes the institutions of the European Union site, the charms of La Petite France, the Krutenau, the Neustadt, etc.

Fortuitously, the departure pier is just steps from the cathedral, on the Quai des Bateliers. Strasbourg very gracefully imparts some of its secrets…

Batorama
18 place de la Cathédrale
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 69 74 44 04

https://www.batorama.com/en

content.title: The Orangerie Park: the oldest garden in the city

introduction.small: Across from the Council of Europe, this natural area is the green lung of the city and a privileged place to stroll, favoured by families of Strasbourg locals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Orangerie Park: the oldest garden in the city

paragraphs.text:
Bordered by the Boulevard of Europe and the Quai Jacoutot, this park is famous for its zoo and the protective presence of a wild-stork reintroduction centre. Success with your children is guaranteed when they see the car track called ‘Driving School', or, if you are with your consort, renting a boat to sail on the lake makes a nice little romantic interlude.

In 1804, the pleasure pavilion that was built there in honour of Josephine de Beauharnais by her Imperial husband (Napoleon Bonaparte, for those who've forgotten their French history) inherited 140 orange trees that were confiscated by revolutionaries. The Josephine Pavilion, destroyed by fire, was eventually rebuilt, but only three orange trees remain, preciously guarded in the park greenhouse.

Subsequently, the park was refurbished as a romantic English garden and then expanded to accommodate the great industrial and craft exhibition of 1895. Many fountains, statues, kiosks, and ice-cream vendors adorn the pathways, making this walk an enchanted moment.

Parc de l'Orangerie
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 61 62 88

https://www.visitstrasbourg.fr/en/things-to-see-and-do/visiting/places-to-visit/parks-and-gardens/f223009094_the-orangerie-park-strasbourg/

content.title: The Palais Rohan: in Louis XV and Napoleon's footsteps

introduction.small: This Baroque palace was built in 1732 for the Cardinal de Soubise, the Prince-Bishop of Strasbourg, based on plans by Robert de Cotte, first architect to the King.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Palais Rohan: in Louis XV and Napoleon's footsteps

paragraphs.text:
Modelled on famous Parisian hotels, between courtyard and gardens, this bishop's palace close to the cathedral is one of the most beautiful architectural achievements of the French 18th century, for both the nobility of its facades and its remarkable interior decoration.

Since 1889, the palace has housed three museums. Some of the great masters of European painting, from the 17th up to the late 19th century (Rubens, Rembrandt, El Greco, Monet, Renoir) may be seen on the walls of the Museum of Fine Arts. If you are a history buff, the Archaeological Museum has fascinating Roman artefacts, while the museum of Decorative Arts exhibits the collections of the Hohenlohe-Museum, founded by German Art historian Wilhelm von Bode and transferred to the Palais Rohan.

The tour is divided into two parts: the apartments of the Rohan cardinals; and the collections of Strasbourg decorative arts from the first French period of 1681 to 1871. Indulge your eyes and your spirit.

Palais Rohan
2 place du Château
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 68 98 51 60

https://en.musees.strasbourg.eu/museum-of-fine-arts

content.title: The Voodoo Museum: a unique collection dedicated to the invisible

introduction.small: This massive building, built by a Berlin architect in the late 19th century, was intended to serve as a water reservoir for steam locomotives.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Voodoo Museum: a unique collection dedicated to the invisible

paragraphs.text:
Listed as a historical monument in 1983, this water tank, vestige of a forgotten industrial heritage, was given a new lease on life by becoming the property of Mark Arbogast.

An Alsatian brewer and a safari enthusiast smitten with Africa and its legends, he entrusted the building's rehabilitation to the architect Michel Moretti. Renamed 'Voodoo Castle', this private museum, the only one of its kind, with more than a thousand objects and works listed, houses the largest collection of West African voodoo objects in the world, from Benin to Ghana, Nigeria and Togo. All the objects on display have been used in religious celebrations, such as ancestor worship, medicine, divination, witchcraft, and other events related to the major stages of the daily life of ethnic groups in the Gulf of Guinea.

A sensitive staging invites you to peculiar encounters with the inexplicable, where you will discover a little-known culture that is still very much alive today.

Musée Vodou
4 rue de Koenigshoffen
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 36 15 03

www.chateau-vodou.com/en/vodou-museum-strasbourg/

content.title: The Alchemist: a cocktail bar with an unusual decor

introduction.small: You must absolutely come before 9:00 p.m. to find a spot in this atypical and incredibly successful bar of the old town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Alchemist: a cocktail bar with an unusual decor

paragraphs.text:
Even the most jaded will agree that this bar is the perfect setting for an uncommon night out. A tercentenary building, restored with respect to the rules of art, houses this boutique bar that makes a point of being different. Unusual, even fantastic, the magical atmosphere borrows codes that have been tried in the sagas of Harry Potter and The Lord of the Rings.

A majestic tree that seems to come out of nowhere grows through the bar and it is by candlelight that you get to know the drinks list of magical potions, whose subtleties are amusing: the Model Mole, Green Mouse, Fidel Castrated (enjoy the puns), Lobotomy, Testament…

It will take a while to decipher and then choose from the impressive range of beers, cocktails, and mocktails, all personalised with humour, a small caption, and the list of ingredients. Fortunately, the wait staff is open and very kind, and happy to answer all your questions.

L'Alchimiste
3 rue des Sœurs
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)9 82 35 48 01

https://www.facebook.com/barlalchimiste

Cocktails: around 8 EUR

content.title: The Buerehiesel: sincere cuisine, rich in emotions

introduction.small: Welcome to the headquarters of chef Eric Westermann, multi-awarded for the continuous high quality of this Strasbourg institution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Buerehiesel: sincere cuisine, rich in emotions

paragraphs.text:
Reservations are a necessity for lunch or dinner in this beautiful half-timbered 17th-century farmhouse with stunning views of the Orangerie Park. At the table, inventive, modern, generous cuisine meets the specifications of a great house. If you are an Epicurean looking for unusual flavours, be prepared for pleasant surprises. Though the menu does not hide its local roots, they have been modernised with aplomb. The selection of gourmet menus contributes, without exception, to a singular taste experience. Among the temptations: filet of smoked eel, stir-fried duck foie gras in poppy on a bed or arugula salad and poultry dressing in Melfor vinegar, or the roasted lobster from Brittany served with tomatoes, watermelon and watermelon juice. Next is the Peking duck filet in spices and grilled buckwheat, with grilled beetroot, raw peaches cooked in Port wine, or even the confit leg of lamb in piquillo juice and argan oil. Keep some room for the unforgettable grapefruit soufflé, with Campari granite and grapefruit sorbet. Impeccable, attentive service complements a wine list that navigates with intelligence between national and local Grands Crus, as well as lesser-known greats.

Le Buerehiesel
4 Parc de l'Orangerie
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 45 56 65

https://www.buerehiesel.fr

Menu: around 76 EUR

content.title: On the wine route

introduction.small: A symbol of epicurean Alsace, the wine route winds its bucolic and serene way through ancient vineyards and beautiful vistas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On the wine route

paragraphs.text:
From Thann to Marlenheim, from north to south in the direction of Colmar, a chain of scenic, floral, wine villages illustrates the richness and diversity of Alsatian vineyards. The route, of great simplicity, is enhanced by the presence of various medieval remains and is a must for all lovers of Grands Crus.

Eguisheim, Kaysersberg, Ribeauvillé, Riquewihr, Andlau, and Obernai all have strong AOC identities who organise in turn, country-style tastings, wine festivals, and harvests in a lively and friendly atmosphere.

The tour of fortified locations and castles, adorned with a beautiful showcase of green vineyards and forests, promises to be a highlight of your trip. If you can go down only one route, take the Nationale 59 to the town of Sélestat and to the famous castle of Haut-Koenigsbourg, a stone sentinel inherited from the Middle Ages, which has survived the centuries.

https://www.wineroute.alsace/

content.title: Europa Park, the one and only theme park

introduction.small: Via the A5 motorway, you only need 45 minutes to reach the town of Rust and one of the most famous theme parks in Europe, which opened in 1975.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Europa Park, the one and only theme park

paragraphs.text:
There are nearly 100 major rides and attractions including 11 roller coasters, an enchanted forest, and several theme areas devoted exclusively to children, which constitute the epicentre of this amazing German leisure complex. It draws a family clientele of nearly five million every year, which places it just after Disneyland Paris in terms of attendance.

You guessed it: diversity is Europa Park's major theme. European countries are represented in 13 distinct neighbourhoods with their specific architecture, landscapes, cuisine, and hobbies. A number of festivities are available in many languages, and there is a wide choice of shows including 20 musicals and a puppet theatre for children.

Besides the wide variety of bars and restaurants, the resort offers high-end accommodation via the presence of five starred hotels, each of which includes all kinds of festivities for children and their parents among their many services.

Europa Park
Europa-Park-Straße 2
77977 Rust
Germany

+49 78 22 77 66 88

https://www.europapark.de/en

content.title: Hotel D: an elegant and refined address

introduction.small: D as in Discovery, Deluxe, and Design for this beautiful contemporary hotel, located close to the main Christmas market.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel D: an elegant and refined address

paragraphs.text:
Though very central, the hotel is on a street paradoxically spared by the hectic noise of the city. The hidden treasures of historic Strasbourg are just across the Pont de la Fonderie bridge next to the hotel, accessible by foot or by bike.

This elegant and refined address is quite unique. To stay in total harmony with the memory of the place, the D gave carte blanche to Sybille de Margerie, an interior designer responsible for a number of successful hotel renovations. Here she modernised Alsatian cultural codes to offer style and soul to the 37 rooms and suites.

A serene atmosphere, rich in colours and subtleties, invites you to rest and relaxation. Go for the attic rooms on the top floor. In addition to stunning views of the city skyline, they are flooded with light.

Hotel D
15 rue du Fossé-des-Treize
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 15 13 67

https://www.hoteld.fr/en/

Rooms: from 79 EUR

content.title: La maison Kammerzell, timbered house masterpiece

introduction.small: Both restaurant and historical monument, Kammerzell is a remarkable late Gothic building with a half-timbered facade that reveals the essence of regional art through the centuries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La maison Kammerzell, timbered house masterpiece

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1427 and now classed as a historic monument, this singular building houses the famous restaurant of the same name since the 19th century, and is a must on any visitor's agenda. The elaborately carved wooden facade frames a remarkable collection of stained-glass windows.

They permit an intimate and cosy light to bathe the inner maze of small rooms and alcoves, which are so convivial for an evening with friends. On the ground floor, there are allegorical frescoes by the Alsatian artist Leo Shnug, defender of German mythology, not to mention the medieval vaults and the monumental 16th-century stone spiral staircase that reflect the splendour of the past. On the first floor, some of the exceptionally comfortable rooms offer stunning views of the cathedral.

The Kammerzell Brasserie, one of the most beautiful in the world, hosts festive dinners around a traditional menu whose international reputation is in perfect harmony with its legendary setting. Patricia Schulz (1,000 Places to See Before You Die) is quite right in including it in her book, so do not miss it.

Maison Kammerzell
16 place de la Cathédrale
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 32 42 14

https://www.maison-kammerzell.com/en/

content.title: La Cour du Corbeau: a hotel exquisitely inspired by history

introduction.small: In the 16th century, the building housed a post office and some illustrious guests, such as the Maréchal de Turenne, the King of Prussia, and Voltaire.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Cour du Corbeau: a hotel exquisitely inspired by history

paragraphs.text:
A member of the MGallery Collection chain, this inspired address, which was also an inn at the time of the tsars, is the promise of a unique experience, especially if you are fond of leaving the beaten path. Just steps from the cathedral, this Renaissance style building comes into its own against this eminently historical backdrop. It is actually one of the oldest in Europe. Worn by the centuries, its majestic courtyard allows a glimpse of secret passageways and remarkable carved woodwork. For the 63 highly distinctive rooms and suites, an intimate atmosphere beautifully portrays the exuberance of the neo-Baroque furniture and the precious, soothing toned fabrics. As an indication of the hotel's commitment to quality the rooms all have 'Sealy Palace' beds, a pledge of international excellence. For a relaxing evening, head to the bar, open from 2:00 p.m. until midnight, or to the tearoom, renowned for its choice of gourmet pastries.

La Cour du Corbeau
6-8 rue des Couples
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 90 00 26 26

https://www.cour-corbeau.com/en/

Rooms: from 132 EUR

content.title: La Maison des Tanneurs: a fixture by the water

introduction.small: At the edge of the River Ill, in the district of La Petite France, this slightly askew building for the tanning of hides has inspired many artists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Maison des Tanneurs: a fixture by the water

paragraphs.text:
You will find this house, and those adjoining it, on all the postcards extolling the charms of Alsace. We must admit that the sight of this traditional row of small traditional houses, old artisan dwellings attached to each other since the Renaissance, is as fascinating as it gets. This venerable institution, whose reputation far exceeds the regions borders, attracts a customer base that appreciates the authenticity of family recipes around the traditional specialties from Alsace. Make a point of stopping here and sitting on the terrace along the river to sample the regional menu served in portions that could not be more generous. An attentive and smiling staff will advise you on the house specialties: homemade duck liver, a Petite France salad, Alsatian-style escargots, young guinea fowl in green pepper on a bed of sauerkraut, duck breast in spices and honey or even the fish sauerkraut. For dessert, you have to indulge in the famous Alsatian parfait, or the iced Kougelhopf in Gewürtzraminer wine pomace. You dreamed of Alsace? Well, here you are!

La Maison des Tanneurs
42 rue du Bain-aux-Plantes
67000 Strasbourg

+33 (0)3 88 32 79 70

https://maison-des-tanneurs.com

Menu: around 50 EUR
